review_title: Stay away from Musicvertising, they do not provide the service they promise.
review_content: My experience with Musicvertisin is very negative. We subscribed for the Spotify channel promotion twice. Yes, I am ashamed that I let them fool me twice.Firstly, we subscribed for the "Business Campaign" in November 2022. We were receiving the promised promotion for a month, even if it looked strange, not balanced, with 30 streams per listener, big peaks followed by silence. It almost went to a standstill for a week before the renewal date but became very active the day before. Once we renewed, the service almost stopped, and we had weeks without any promotion. Each time I complained, I had lots of promises but no action. So I cancelled, but I received a lot of messages and promises, one of them stating that there was a bug in my promotion, and it was fixed, and they will compensate me. I signed again, this time for the Diamond channel promotion, the most expensive - $1,999 per month. I was promised stable, consistent promotion in writing. It went to a standstill at the end of the month again, but just three days before renewal it picked up. And completely stopped for a week after.Again, during the second month, I had three weeks without a promotion. The listeners dropped by 74%, and the streams dropped by %47. The followers also dropped, but I think those FOLLOWER S ARE TOTALLY FAKE - they never picked out our new releases. The Spotify algorithmic streams dropped to the level before promotion. Now PLAYLISTS: During four months of promotion, we were given FOUR placements in the playlist. During the same time, I secured over 50 placements on SubmitHub... However, Musicvertising playlists are FAKE - they have lots of followers etc, but they are not played. I did not see any plays from Musicverising playlists.SO THE CONCLUSION: perhaps MusicVertising is not using bots, perhaps they are legit, and perhaps they are not scammers. It is difficult to prove. But for sure, they just do not have the capacity to provide the service they promise. Stay away from this costly fake service.

review_title: What actually happens during the advertisement campaign
review_content: So, to give credit where credit’s due, the number of streams of my music has grown, though by a small margin. Hovewer, it seems that this company uses some loopholes in Spotify TOS and then just tell you that they “fully comply” with them. I will just tell you what I can based on closely watching my Spotify artist stats during the campaign.1. Streams come and go in “waves”. E.g. today you have 100 streams on your music, tomorrow - 1000, a day after that - 500 and three days later 100 streams again. That’s a pattern that was being repeated over and over during one month of the advertisement campaign. 2. A majority of streams was being made using an unknown type of device. Spotify stats differentiate if people were listening to your music using their smartphone, PC, gaming console, e.t.c. Before the campaign those stats for my music were distributed pretty naturally, with 70-80% listening on their smartphones. However, after the campaign started, nearly 50-60% of streams came from the device type “Other”, which is a huge red flag in my opinion.3. Spotify stats also differentiate between streams that were made from your artist page , user’s own playlists, editorial playlists and algorithmic playlists. During the campaign the percentage was thus: 60% from the artist page, nearly 30% from user’s own playlist and around 10% from other people playlists. To ensure those 30+10% this company makes a clever little thing: the streams are EVENLY distributed between the user playlists that already contain a song in question and a playlist that contains ONLY the track in question with the same name as the track is created (there were such playlists for EVERY single track in my album) and a lot of streams come from this playlist too, which is suspicious to say the least.4. Followers. New followers appear in a pattern that looks like a staircase on a graph.  Every X days, almost the same amount of followers are subscribing to you, which is extremely reminiscent of youtube bot raids. Another funny detail - in the previous reviews the company representative answered that follower drop (that happened to me in the end of april) has happened because Spotify are deleting inactive accounts. But, at least in my case, if i put a ruler onto the followers graph (i am not smart enough to do actual maths) before the advertisement campaign it looked like an even uphill line, which is natural. Then, there is the aforementioned “staircase”, a plateau, a huge follower drop, and then the graph continues naturally in an uphill fashion. The funny thing is, if i put a ruler to the beginning of a follower graph (which is a date when i made a first release and promoted it on my youtube channel) and connect it with today’s date, those couple weeks after the campaign ended look like a natural continuation of a slightly-uphill graph before the campaign, and the follower drop actually had “stabilized” it to that level. If what I am trying to say is too cryptic and complicated - it looks like those followers that are allegedly not bots and that have followed me during the campaign ALL were deleted from my account and in the end they had no impact on the graph angle and trend whatsoever. So, they may not be bots, but they may be free accounts registered en masse by this company for use in their services (it’s the best case, the worst is those are hacked accounts).So, this company may not be LITERALLY using bots, but nobody defines what is “a bot” in this case. Also, they may comply with Spotify TOS (at least for now) but likely are using loopholes in it. They use semantic and legal loopholes in order to make it look like the services they provide are legit:2 stars and not 1 because I have a little more streams now.
